data.q: Which design pattern ensures only one instance of a class is created?
data.e: The Singleton Pattern restricts instantiation so only one instance of a class exists.

data.q: Which design pattern provides a way to create objects without specifying the exact class?
data.e: The Factory Pattern abstracts object creation, allowing flexibility in instantiation.

data.q: Which design pattern allows objects to be notified when another object changes state?
data.e: The Observer Pattern establishes a one-to-many dependency so observers are updated automatically.

data.q: Which design pattern lets you add new behavior to objects dynamically?
data.e: The Decorator Pattern attaches additional responsibilities to objects without modifying their structure.

data.q: Which design pattern allows incompatible interfaces to work together?
data.e: The Adapter Pattern translates one interface into another, enabling interoperability.

data.q: Which design pattern involves cloning existing objects to create new ones?
data.e: The Prototype Pattern creates new objects by copying existing ones, reducing overhead.

data.q: Which design pattern separates object construction from its representation?
data.e: The Builder Pattern allows step-by-step construction of complex objects.
